question: The legendary Captain James West and I finally got him all to myself.
answer: That's right, sugar, and you should feel free to treat him just bad. General McGrath's boys. I thought y'all was never gonna show up.

question: Mister West, you wouldn't be here workin' tonight, now would you?
answer: No, no. 'Course not. Not tonight. Would you be working if you were up here with you?

question: Good. Jim!
answer: Ah, this hole is a safety issue. I'm thinking, what if it starts to rain and the water level goes up. It could suck you right up. I'm protecting you.

question: Problem solved.
answer: Belle, you don't just ram a man's underbritches into a knothole. You wanna plug the hole, you ram your own britches in there.

question: Oh, Jim.
answer: Much as I'd like to take credit for that you might need to hand me my gun... ... Hand me my gun. Okay, who just made a wish? Was it you? I could sure use those clothes now. Fought five long years with the Union Army not to hear that word again. And you boys lost, remember? How 'bout some pants!? Could I have a little privacy here? Thank you. You'll have to excuse me, darlin'... but my evidence is getting away. Sorry about there not being any towels. Backwards-ass bumpkins got a wagon full of nitro...! Whoa now...! I said, whoa!!! Well, well, this is workin' out to be a perfect day. My man... ... General Bloodbath McGrath.

question: Much as I'd like to take credit for that you might need to hand me my gun... ... Hand me my gun. Okay, who just made a wish? Was it you? I could sure use those clothes now. Fought five long years with the Union Army not to hear that word again. And you boys lost, remember? How 'bout some pants!? Could I have a little privacy here? Thank you. You'll have to excuse me, darlin'... but my evidence is getting away. Sorry about there not being any towels. Backwards-ass bumpkins got a wagon full of nitro...! Whoa now...! I said, whoa!!! Well, well, this is workin' out to be a perfect day. My man... ... General Bloodbath McGrath.
answer: Good. You're going to be my little doggy. And when I say 'speak,' you tell me everything I want to know. Understood? All right, little doggy. Sit up. Now tell me who's in the sack next door. Is it the scientist, Dr. Escobar? Speak! Speak words, dumb doggy! Tell me the name of the man you kidnapped him for... Watch the swirling spiral! Lie down, bad dog!

question: Didn't mean to startle you, ma'am. Looked like you could use some help.
answer: Looks can be deceivin'... dark stranger. I am perfectly fine.

question: I can see that, darlin'. Woman of your caliber probably gets top dollar, too. So here you go. You can run along. I'll take care of McGrath. C'mon, lady. You got the money. Have a little dignity.
answer: Leave him right there. Let's go, Hudson... hands! Thank... you.

question: U.S. Army... Now get outta my way, lady!
answer: I'm no lady! I'm a U.S. Marshal! You get out of my way!

question: So now what...? This gun? Or this one?
answer: Gentlemen! Don't make Captain West any later for his appointment than he already is! Been a lot of death threats lately ... Cabinet made me hire some damn detectives. Drink, cigar?

question: Thank you, sir.
answer: I hear you let General McGrath get away?

question: Sir, I had him right in my hands when some half-a-sissy wearin' a dress ruined...
answer: Artemus Gordon.

question: You... know him?
answer: Of course I know him, he's the best marshal I've got! He's a genius. Gordon has proven himself time and again as a very cunning operator with a rapacious intellect. Nothing will stop him from completing a mission for his President... except the impulsive actions of a headstrong cowboy!

question: Who are you?
answer: I am the President of the United States!

question: Wrong answer. Who are you?
answer: I am the President of... ... I'm Artemus Gordon.

question: The President went to West Point ... not Harvard.
answer: Will somebody tell me what the hell this stunt is all about!?!

question: Figures.
answer: I call it the Bi-axle Nitro- Combust...

question: Save it. I've gotta train to catch. Yee-haaa!!
answer: Avant!!!

question: Stop this train!! You hear me!?!
answer: Thanks for dropping in.

question: Forget the bikes, the beards, the fake boobies. Put down the needlepoint and let's settle this like men!
answer: As a matter of clarification, this isn't needlepoint. This is. Right now, I'm putting the final touches on a new invention of my creation. I call it... The Impermeable. It's a vest that, when worn under the clothing, can stop any modern bullet fired even at close range.

question: Really?
answer: But it hasn't been really tested empirically yet.

question: Get up!
answer: Guns. I find them so primitive and unnecessary... if one has done one's proper planning.

question: Yeah? How do you feel about a fist?
answer: I must tell you, Mr. West, I've always felt that allowing a situation to degenerate into physical violence is a failure on my part.

question: Well then, 'Mr.' Gordon, you failed.
answer: I'm sorry, Mr. West, you brought this on yourself. I love this train! The President asked for my suggestions on how to make the Wanderer both comfortable and functional... And while you're down there, you may want to avail yourself of my Sub-carriage Inter-rail Egressor...

question: Only one doin' any 'egressin' is gonna be you.
answer: Perhaps the President was right about us putting aside our petty differences. (recites above the

question: New Orleans.
answer: Shall we let Professor Morton decide?

question: Who?
answer: Meet Professor Thaddeus Morton, expert in the field of metallurgy ... discovered in a field of alfalfa. Kidnapped from M.I.T. six months ago.

question: That's a man's head!
answer: ... And this magnetic collar was around it when his body was discovered. Haven't figured that one out yet...

question: That's a man's head.
answer: According to the Retinal Terminus Theory... a dying person's last conscious image is burned into the back of the eyeball like a photograph. Perhaps there's a clue there... Morton's last image!

question: That's a man's head!
answer: Ah. The refraction of the lenses causes the image to appear upside down. We simply...

question: It's McGrath. I was right all along.
answer: He seems to have something in his pocket... too fuzzy to read, though... Mortification of the aqueous humor seems to have led to the loss of...

question: ... glasses. 'Friends of the South! Come to a Surprise Costume Ball. April 14, eight-thirty. 346 Garden Street... ' Like I said.... New Orleans.
answer: How about this? You could come as my man servant? How about this? You could come as my man servant.

question: Oh yes, Massa Gordon, dats what I'll do. And I'll jus' smile and do as I's tole so those people won' ever know that I would rather shoot myself in the head than play your god damned man servant!
answer: I have a horse costume. You could be the head.

question: The only thing I need to wear is this.
answer: Okay, if you insist on carrying a firearm, I have something I think you'll find intriguing... And it would go nicely with this...

question: Jim West does not wear a dress.
answer: Then what's your plan?

question: How 'bout this
answer: An armed, Negro cowboy costume, how creative. In a room full of white Southerners, you oughtta fit right in. You might even win first prize! Listen to me. The art of disguise is what's going to get us into that party, thus allowing us to find these kidnapped scientists before they're forced to create something that will destroy this great country. Now you and I are the chosen ones, Jim. We're under direct orders from the President himself. And our mission is clear

question: Let me tell you a little something about beloved 'art of disguise'... That night at Fat-Can's, I knew you weren't a woman.
answer: But I was propositioned by three men.

question: Gordon, you looked nasty. Your breasts were all hard and stiff, and were sticking straight out like two rusty cannons on a sunken ship.
answer: These are a work of art. Scientifically and aesthetically perfect.

question: They look like shit.
answer: Touch them.

question: I don't wanna touch 'em. I can see I don't like 'em.
answer: What, are you afraid you're wrong? Touch my breasts.

question: There, Gordon, you happy? I'm touching your breasts.
answer: Not so rough. The buckwheat'll come out.

question: Buckwheat? That's your problem.
answer: What are you doing?

question: Now, squeeze this. This is what a breast should feel like.
answer: Whoa...

question: Isn't that nice?
answer: Very nice.

question: Now touch yourself.
answer: You win. I'm hard.

question: ... West. Jim West. Actually I'm, uh trying to surprise an old friend -- General McGrath. Seen him around anywhere?
answer: I don't believe that name was on our guest list. And I would know. I'm Dr. Loveless's personal assistant.

question: Dr. Arliss Loveless...? One of the great founders of the Confederacy with Jefferson Davis. Funny how most people think he's dead.
answer: Tonight's his coming-out party. See anybody that looks familiar?

question: Matter of fact, I do.
answer: I'm... jealous. Meet me later... in the foyer.

question: Don't you just hate that song? Why, y'all look like you've seen a ghost! It's me, dear friends, alive and kicking! Well, alive, anyway... We may've lost the war, but heaven knows... we haven't lost our sense of humor! Not even when we've lost a lung... a spleen... a bladder... two legs... thirty-five feet of small intestine and our ability to reproduce... All in the name of the South... ... do we lose our sense of humor. I owe a deep debt of gratitude to my friends across the sea for their comfort and... succor. So...! Mi casa es su casa! Ma maison est a vous! Let the party begin!!! Mr. West, how nice of you to join us tonight... and add color to these monochromatic proceedings.
answer: Well, when a man comes back from the dead, it's an occasion to stand and be counted.

question: Miss East informs me that you were expecting to meet General McGrath here. I knew him years ago... but haven't seen him in a coon's age.
answer: I bet a man like yourself would find it difficult to keep in touch with even half the people you know.

question: Perhaps the lovely Miss East will keep you from being a slave to your disappointment.
answer: Well, you know beautiful women... they encourage you one second, cut the legs out from under you the next. Hey, honey... I see a big ole spider up on the wall. Hope it doesn't drop down your pretty dress.

question: I feel as if we know each other from someplace...?
answer: Try again, buster...!

question: Ma'am, please! While I realize I look like something straight out of James Fenimore Cooper... I mean you no harm. My name is Artemus Gordon. And you look like you're in trouble.
answer: Really? I'm Rita. I was hired here as an entertainer. Not that I'm complaining, but what are you doin' in here?

question: Looking for some missing scientists... not that I'm complaining. I'm a special U.S. Marshal on assignment from the President.
answer: If you're so special, how come you're lookin' up here when Loveless has 'em all workin' down in the dungeon? Get me out of here and I'll take you down there.

question: Too late. The 'dungeon' is cleaned out. It was the first place I checked, right after I sampled the gumbo. Bit heavy on the okra.
answer: Thank you... Artemus, was it?

question: One doesn't forget a smile like that. Now where in the world was it...? Have you ever played the Empire Room... the Bijou Cafe perhaps...?
answer: Can I have everyone's attention please. I think we've had a series of major misunderstandings and I'd like to take a moment to clear them up. First, the whole drumming on the boobies thing. In my native land, Africa, my ancestors used drums to communicate between villages. I'm sure y'all can see that this young girl here can communicate all the way down to Baton Rouge. Hell, on a clear day, we might even get Galveston. All I was saying was, 'How're you doing,' 'My name's Jim,' 'How's your mama?' Second misunderstanding. That redneck comment. I'm getting the sense that some of you took that negatively. You know, some of my best friends are whiskey-guzzling, pot-bellied rednecks just like y'all here. That slavery thing, I don't see what the big deal was. Hell, who wouldn't want somebody to run around for them doing chores. Are you going to get your big, fat, lazy ass out of bed every morning and pick your own damn cotton. I don't think so. Let's head on inside and knock back some shine. Come on, back inside. No. Okay. I stand before you as a man who realizes he has done something wrong and I am prepared to do the right thing. Will you marry me? I'll take that as a no. Darling, would it help at all if I said I thought you were a man? Guess not.

question: Hey-yaa!!!
answer: Hang 'm...! Hang'm!?!

question: Meet my trigger-happy partner, James West... who doesn't seem to realize that my carefully planned diversion gave me the opportunity to search for the missing scientists.
answer: Scientist, huh.

question: This is Rita. I found her locked in a cage in Loveless's bedroom. She's an entertainer.
answer: Um, maybe I haven't been quite honest about that... My name is Rita Escobar. I came to find Guillermo Escobar, the scientist, my... father.

question: Professor Escobar?! He was the one I almost rescued that night when... That's where I know you from! Fat-Can Candy's... you sang before I did.
answer: Excuse me?

question: It just rolls on and on. Makes a screeching sound -- like a wounded animal. Got a 'cabin' on top with a cannon... swivels 'round like an eagle's head.
answer: You saw it?

question: Heard about it. Thought it was crazy survivors' stories.
answer: What survivors? There aren't any here.

question: New Liberty, Illinois -- the free slave town just over the border. Just one week before the War ended in '65. I was in the 9th Cavalry that discovered it. Old men, women, children... they used them for target practice... That's when I vowed to follow McGrath to the end of the earth. I was hoping to kill you myself.
answer: That's a nice way to talk to people.

question: What do you mean? Where is he? Where did he go?!
answer: Well, I know that. I'll tell you if you take me along.

question: Just tell me.
answer: The girls at the mansion. They talk. 'I vonder if my hair vill get frissy in ze desert...? Vhere is diss Ooo-tah anyvay?'

question: I don't see why we couldn't have given her a ride back home to Texas. It is on the way...
answer: On the way to Utah where our President happens to be. Maybe we oughta be worryin' about that little coincidence!

question: We wouldn't have known where Loveless was going if it wasn't for her. Seems a bit ungracious. Possibly perilous.
answer: Look, all that would happen would be she'd get in our way and I'd probably wind up gettin' in the saddle with her.

question: Funny that you say that. Because I thought she was more interested in me. You know, I've been trying to place myself in Loveless's shoes...
answer: Good luck on that one.

question: Ha, ha, ha... You know, I can't imagine what Loveless -- a man without any reproductive organs could possibly want with Rita. Not that Rita doesn't have a figure that would inspire a Botticelli... or a Raphael. ... especially her breasts. Did you notice the way one of them... Both of them actually... to say nothing of her buttocks... ... and the group of foreign ministers at Loveless's party... What were they doing there? Here's France, Spain and Britain... How long has she been here?
answer: Since the first breast.

question: I am so embarrassed.
answer: I'll spare you. Make yourself a sandwich to take with you. You're getting off.

question: I've got somethin' you might use. It ain't stylish, but it's practical... Loveless kidnapped two chemists, that means there's gonna be explosives. He's got a metallurgist, so there's gonna be heavy armor. And he's got Rita's father, who -- according to you -- is the world's foremost specialist in hydraulics. Which means, whatever it is... it's gonna move. So what, is he building that's gonna make the President fall to his knees and surrender the country?
answer: A bedside heater.

question: What?
answer: Rita. She needs a bedside heater. I mean, it gets cold in there, you know, with the stained glass window right over the -- Such a pleasant girl. A real breath of fresh ass.

question: You said ass.
answer: Did I? No...

question: Gordon, get out your little tool kit and get this damn thing off of me!
answer: 'Gentlemen, welcome to the Loveless Experimental Camp for Political Dissidents. There are no guards. No barbed wire. As long as you stay within the designated perimeter, you will stay alive.'

question: I don't have time for this.
answer: Wait, I have an auxiliary tool kit!

question: See? Nothing happened.
answer: Oh, really...?

question: Head for that gully!
answer: When I give the signal. Jump off the cliff into my arms.

question: Are you crazy?! Do you see what's down there?
answer: Five, four, three, two...

question: Forget it. I'm not doing it...
answer: One...

question: Oh shit! I just remembered... I can't swim!
answer: You won't have to! Maybe I should have stayed inside that fence another moment or two. All right, Gordon, what's your plan? How are you gonna get this damn thing off my neck?

question: Excuse me?
answer: Isn't that why you're here? 'Cause you're the master of, you know, mechanical stuff?

question: Oh. Oh, I see. Now I'm the master of... 'mechanical stuff.' As opposed to five minutes ago, when I was trying to collect my thoughts and figure out a way to get us out of these contraptions! But no! -- That wouldn't have been any fun for a certain somebody, and I won't mention any names -- Jim West! -- who decided to take me on a bracing romp through a cornfield and play a fanciful game of hide and seek with serrated, spinning death discs, while our only mode of transportation is in the hands of a sadistic madman with weapons of mass destruction, who kidnapped Rita, and is on his way to kill our President and take over the country!
answer: Hey, calm down, Gordon...

question: No! Because I'm the 'Master of Mechanical Stuff!' And I have to help YOU! Because you're the 'Master of Stupid Stuff!'
answer: Gordon...

question: You want to get that collar off? Fine! Let's do it the fun, Jim West way! Let's bash it with a rock!
answer: Gordon, you don't want to do that.

question: Oh, but I do. That's odd. What did you do?
answer: I didn't do shit!

question: No, you must've reversed the polarity of the magnets.
answer: I did not do shit! That's it --

question: Are you all right?
answer: Oh, I'm peachey. Now help me get my boot off! Ahhhh!

question: Apologies, apologies.
answer: Do me a favor. When you're telling this story to your grandkids, leave this part out.

question: Don't worry.
answer: Now, when I undo your belt, I'm going to run as fast as I can that way, and you run as fast as you can the other way. Understand?

question: You're going to run as fast as you can one way and I'm going to run as fast as I can the other...? Ingenious.
answer: One... two... Three! Get off me, you steaming pile of !

question: I'm trying, you son of a !
answer: you!

question: yourself!
answer: I do not want to spend the rest of my life looking like a meatball on a plate.

question: We're going to have to discuss bathroom etiquette soon. Very soon. Aha. My auxiliary tool kit. I forgot all about it. It must've slipped out of my pocket.
answer: Your pocket? Why wasn't it attached to some spring-loaded something-or-other that shoots out of your ass?

question: Because that, my friend, would be uncomfortable.
answer: Why didn't you tell me you had an 'auxiliary' tool kit?

question: I did tell you, but in your zeal to run and leap off a two-hundred- foot cliff, I don't think you heard me.
answer: What?!

question: '... Take physic, pomp; Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel, That thou mayst shake the superflux to them, And show the heavens more just.' What?!
answer: You know, Gordon, you can be quite annoying -- flaunting that fancy education.

question: Well, truth be told, I never had a fancy education -- not a formal one, anyway.
answer: The Harvard thing seems pretty formal to me.

question: This ring? This ring isn't real. Do you want it? A prop. I'm an actor. Or was. I gave it up. I went by the name of Arthur Gordon. Ever hear of me?
answer: No. How did you wind up in this line of work?

question: The pinnacle of my life in the theater came in a production of Our American Cousin -- a light comedy -- at Ford's Theater in Washington. There was this one line I had... always got the biggest laugh in the show. One night, it drowned out the gunshot that killed President Lincoln. I decided to devote my talents to making sure that never happened again. Uh... There's a spider on your hand. Doesn't that bother you?
answer: She doesn't want any trouble. She's just trying to get warm.

question: How come you know so much about the desert, anyway?
answer: The Indians taught me. I lived out here when I was a boy. Hey -- watch -- The desert wasp... one of the world's great hunters. She'll kill the tarantula -- and lay her eggs on it, so her babies can have something to eat.

question: Now I'm really hungry. How did your parents, who I assume were Negroes, feel about you being raised by Indians?
answer: They didn't have much to say about it. I was sent to another plantation when I was little. Ran away as soon as my legs were strong enough to take me.

question: Did you ever see your family again?
answer: Yeah... They were at the camp at New Liberty.

question: I'll help you get him, Jim. You have no idea where you're going, do you?
answer: I know exactly where I'm goin' ... Spider Canyon. But I'm never gonna get there with you draggin' that damn thing around!

question: While a magneto of this power may not inspire your scientific curiosity, it does mine. Besides, you never know when it might come in handy.
answer: Arte... when you're right, you're right.

question: Well I think our partnership is taking a big step forward. You finally admitted I was right about something. Now... how about admitting you were lost?
answer: Don't push it.

question: Jim, I know I've hallucinated it several times before, so is that really the Wanderer?
answer: That's the Wanderer.

question: And would it be too much to hope that I'm simply seeing a World's Fair down there... ?
answer: Yeah, it would. That's Loveless' Lair.

question: Now that's impressive.
answer: Nice to see an invention that actually works.

question: We'll see about that. The fool doesn't even realize he's trapped.
answer: Gordon, let's ride! You do know how to ride...? ... A horse, I mean.

question: Yes... I know how to ride a horse. When the situation calls for something primitive.
answer: How about now? There's a big spider stompin' towards our President!

question: I was just thinking about another spider. Remember in the desert, when that little wasp killed the tarantula...?
answer: Yeah. Well, the wasp had a small advantage. It could fly.

question: Exactly! In 1540, Leonardo Da Vinci invented a flying machine called the 'Ornithopter.' Though he never actually flew it...
answer: Artemus! There's no time for plans or half-cocked inventions! They don't work. We gotta stick to what we're each good at!

question: May God continue the unity of our country... ... as this railroad unites the two great oceans of this world.
answer: Well, isn't this a coincidence! I'm out for a little mornin' ride, and right in the middle of nowhere, I bump into General Ulysses S. Grant himself! We've never been properly introduced. I'm Dr. Arliss Loveless, formerly with the Confederate Army.

question: Yes, Dr. Loveless, what can I do for you today? Flank him, left and right.
answer: I have a humble abode nearby, and I hope you'll accept my hospitality. I have a little proposition to make.

question: What proposition is that?
answer: The unconditional and immediate surrender of the United States of America to the Loveless Alliance.

question: I didn't realize we were at war.
answer: How about now...? Now just who are you?

question: Ha... Ha... Hangtown girls...
answer: Not to sound ungrateful, but you're a little over the top.

question: Ha... Ha... Ha...
answer: Let me warn you about that dress...

question: Coleman! Must you smoke when handling explosives!
answer: He's just a little nervous 'cause no one's ever flown before. Avant...! Avant!!!

question: We're not getting enough lift! We need more speed!
answer: Hey, uh... that's the cliff over there, you know?

question: Yes, I do know. It worked...? It worked!!
answer: If you had to get one right, I'm real glad it was this one.

question: I think I'll call it...
answer: Lemme guess... an Elevation Enhancer?

question: No, Air... Gordon.
answer: Go down, down there!

question: You can't just 'go down there.' Flight depends on lift, which must be calibrated to the angle of descent...
answer: Shut up and go down there, will ya?

question: For almost four long years I've been trackin' the animal responsible for the Massacre at New Liberty. And I hear that's you...
answer: Please, West... show a little mercy to a poor defenseless cripple...

question: Now, now, Doctor... let's not cloud this otherwise sunny day with that poor-ol'-me-cripple-talk. Just buck up and say to yourself, 'I am indefatigably hard-pumpin' and steely!'
answer: After I kill ya, I swear I'm gonna boil you down to axle grease!

question: Now that's the ol' doctor I know!
answer: Well, I'll be a monkey's uncle. How did we arrive in this dark situation?

question: I don't know. Guess I'm stumped!
answer: And I'm so cotton-pickin' afraid of heights. They just give me the spooks!

question: Ah, don't be afraid, Loveless. With this being the last leg of our journey and all, you should soak in the view, you're really missing something.
answer: Mister West, I'm gonna cut this conversation short...

question: Good one, Loveless. I didn't think of that one.
answer: Mister West!!! I am faced with a difficult decision here. On one hand, there is the overwhelming love that I have for myself, and on the other, the raw, seething hatred I have for you! Now, I could kill you very easily, just by pulling this lever... But, of course, I would die along with you. I guess the only thing that I can take comfort in is the hope that you would hit those rocks a second before me and I could enjoy immeasurable bliss before I vanish. What to do, what to do...

question: Allow me to make that decision easy on you, Loveless. Because I want to see you dead a hell of a lot more than I want to live.
answer: Why is it that I have a sneaking suspicion, that although you are as black as the night on the outside... inside, you are yellow?! You don't have it in you, do you... boy?!

question: You were right. Let's cut this conversation short!
answer: Weeeeeeeeeest!!!!

question: Gentlemen, I now strongly believe the United States is going to be truly united. Not because of this railroad... but because of you. I've signed into law the creation of an agency whose sole duty is to protect the President and the country from lunatics like Loveless. Welcome to the Secret Service, Agents No. 1 and No. 2.
answer: Uh, just out of curiosity, sir... who's Agent No. 1?

question: I don't think that matters very much, do you? Gordon? Besides, you'll have plenty of time to discuss it on your new assignment. See you back in Washington.
answer: But, sir... what about our train?

question: She's not really an entertainer, remember?
answer: I can't go with either of you. It's not that you both don't have your attributes. You're so sophisticated and such a wonderful cook. Jim, you're good with a gun... and have great legs. And you're both so brave. But... I'm afraid I haven't been completely honest with you. Professor Escobar's not my father. He's my husband.

question: Rita... why didn't you just tell us that in the first place?
answer: Well, I was going to... but would you have really brought me along if I said I was married? Honestly. I didn't think so. At least you still have each other.
